QUALITY
Westerns together with the Nuwara Eliyas were lower to last, whilst the Uva/Uda Pussellawas were barely maintained. Low Growns were similar to last.
Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 2
Page 2
COMMENTS
The penultimate sale of the year concluded today had on offer a total of 5.8 M/Kgs, down from the 6.1 M/Kgs on offer the previous week. In general, there was fair demand, whilst there was an easier trend in prices for most varieties of tea with a fairly significant decline being recorded for the High & Medium liquoring BOP/BOPF grades.
Ex-Estate offerings totalled 0.93 M/Kgs, up from a 0.88 M/Kgs on offer the previous week. Overall quality of teas from the Western slopes were lower to last, whilst teas from the Eastern sector showed no significant change.
Best Western BOP/BOPF's had on offer a few select invoices which sold around last week's levels, whilst the majority declined by up to Rs. 100 per kg. In the Below Best category, BOP/BOPF's - particularly in the higher price bracket - declined by Rs. 50 per kg and more. At the lower end, BOP's declined by Rs. 50-100 per kg, whilst the corresponding BOPF's declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more as the sale progressed. Nuwara Eliya BOP/BOPF's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa BOP's declined by Rs. 50 per kg and more, whilst the corresponding BOPF's lost up to Rs. 100 per kg. Uva - Select Best BOP invoices declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others declined substantially more. Corresponding BOPF's - Select Best invoices were Rs. 20-40 per kg easier, whilst the others eased further and substantially more by the close.
High & Medium Grown CTC teas - BP1's had hardly any offerings, whilst the PF1's followed a similar trend with prices declining by up to Rs. 50 per kg and more for the better invoices, and to a lesser extent, at the lower end of the market. Low Grown varieties - BP1's continued to sell well, whilst the PF1's too sold reasonably well around last week's levels.
No doubt a disappointing sale, particularly for the liquoring teas!!
Less activity from shippers to the CIS, whilst the other traditional markets too were fairly selective and in general, the intensity of buying was less.
Low Growns comprised of 2.3 M/Kgs. All categories met with fair demand.
In the Leafy and Semi-Leafy catalogues, Select Best BOP1's were easier, whilst the Best varieties together with the Below Best and bolder varieties maintained. Teas at the bottom too followed a similar trend. OP1's, in general, were easier. Well-made OP's were easier, whilst the Below Best and teas at the bottom together with the shorter varieties declined sharply. High-priced OPA's were easier, whilst the balance maintained. Select Best PEK's declined, whilst the Best, Below Best and clean leaf teas at the bottom were easier. PEK1's, in general, were irregularly lower.
FBOP's together with a few Select Best FF1's were firm, whilst the Best and Below Best declined. Cleaner Leaf teas at the bottom were firm to dearer, whilst the balance were irregular.
In the Premium catalogue, Very Tippy teas were firm to dearer, whilst the Best and Below Best too followed a similar trend. The balance were irregular following quality.
NOTE
Next week's Auction (Sale No. 51) is a one-day auction and is scheduled for Monday, 23 December 2024
SRI LANKA TEA EXPORTS - NOVEMBER 2024
Key Highlights:
* Monthly Exports have been recorded at 20.07 M/Kgs - (Decrease of 1.38 M/Kgs against 2023)
* F.O.B Value records Rs. 1,718.88 for the month (USD 5.92) - (Decrease of Rs. 6.89 and an increase of USD 0.64 against 2023)
*
Cumulative Exports recorded 223.22 M/Kgs - (Increase of 2.06 M/Kgs YoY)
* Cumulative F.O.B Value reaches Rs. 1,769.93 (USD 5.88), recording a Rs. 2.48 decrease and increase of USD 0.45 against the corresponding year-to date period of 2023.
* Iraq retains the top position amongst leading importer countries of Ceylon Tea for the
cumulative period in 2024
November 2024/2023
* Tea Exports for the month of November 2024 totalled 20.07 M/Kgs, showing a negative variance of 1.38 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 21.46 M/Kgs of November 2023. All categories show negative variances except for Tea Packets which has recorded a marginal gain in comparison with the corresponding month of the previous year. FOB value in November 2024 was recorded at Rs. 1,718.88, a decline of Rs. 6.89 YoY compared to Rs. 1,725.77 of November 2023 (Refer table below).
JANUARY-NOVEMBER 2024/2023
*
January-November 2024 cumulative exports totalled 223.22 M/Kgs, recording an increase of 2.06 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 221.16 M/Kgs of January-November 2023. Tea Packets and Instant Tea categories have recorded negative variances, whilst Tea in Bulk, Tea Bags and Green Tea categories have shown positive variances against the same period of the previous year.
* FOB value for the period stood at Rs. 1,769.93, a decrease of Rs. 2.48 (increase of USD 0.45) vis-à-vis Rs. 1,772.41 of January-November 2023.
* All categories except for Tea in Bulk and Tea Packets showed negative variances in LKR terms in FOB value, whilst gains were recorded in USD terms in all categories when compared to the corresponding period in 2023 (Refer table below).
Iraq ranks at No. 01 amongst major importers of Ceylon Tea with a total of 30.37 M/Kgs, a marginal decline of 1% YoY in January-November 2024 against the previous year's 30.53 M/Kgs, whilst Russia at 2
nd
place has witnessed an increase of 12% YoY with 22.88 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 20.52M/Kgs recorded in 2023. The U.A.E with 19.61 M/Kgs (20% increase YoY) followed by Türkiye 16.39 M/Kgs (42% decrease YoY), China 10.67 M/Kgs (6% decrease YoY) and Iran 9.58 M/Kgs (84% increase YoY) have been cited as other notable importers of Ceylon Tea during the period of January-November 2024.
(Refer statistical details on Page Nos. 8 and 9).
FORBES & WALKER TEA BROKERS (PVT) LTD SALE OF - 16TH/ 17TH DECEMBER 2024
Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 3
Page 3
MARKET
Irregularly easier and a high volume of unsold teas
HIGH GROWN TEAS
BOP
Best Western's - A few select invoices were firm, whilst the others declined by up to Rs. 100 per kg. Teas in the Below Best category declined by Rs. 50 per kg and more following quality. Plainer sorts were Rs. 50-100 per kg easier. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's declined by Rs. 50 per kg and more. Uva's - Select Best invoices were Rs. 20-40 per kg easier, whilst the others declined substantially more.
BOPF
Best Western's - A few select invoices were firm, whilst the others declined by up to Rs. 100 per kg. In the Below Best category, teas in the higher price bracket declined by Rs. 50 per kg and more following quality, whilst the others together with the Plainer sorts declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more by the close. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's declined by up to Rs. 100 per kg and more. Uva's - Select Best invoices were Rs. 20-40 per kg easier, whilst the others eased further and substantially more by the close.
OP/OPA
Well-made OP/OPA's declined by Rs. 50 per kg, whilst the others at the lower end were fully firm to selectively dearer.
PEKOE/PEKOE1
A limited selection of flavoury PEK's that were available, were irregularly easier. Orthodox Leafy PEK/PEK1's were easier by Rs. 50 per kg.  Best Rotovane PEK's decline by Rs. 50 per kg and more following quality/special inquiry, whilst the others and poorer sorts declined further.
FBOP/FBOPF1
Flavoury FBOP's were mostly unsold. Well-made Orthodox Leafy FBOPs were firm on last, whilst the FF1's in general were easier by Rs. 50-100 per kg.

OFF GRADES
FGS1/FGS
Select Best varieties were firm to easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more following quality. Below Best varieties declined by Rs. 40-50 per kg and more, whilst the teas at the bottom end of the market were irregular. Low Growns - Clean Leaf varieties which were maintained at the commencement of the sale, declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg towards the latter part of the sale. CTC's - In general, were firm.
BROKENS
Main Grade reducer varieties in the Best category were firm, whilst the balance were easier by Rs. 20-30 per kg. Below Best varieties were firm to dearer by Rs. 10-20 per kg, whilst the poorer sorts were firm to easier by Rs. 20 per kg.
BOP1A
Main Grade reducer varieties in the Best category declined by Rs. 50-100 per kg, whilst the balance were irregular. Below Best varieties were dearer by Rs. 20-30 per kg and more, on occasion. Poorer sorts in general were firm, whilst select invoices gained by Rs. 20-30 per kg.

CROP AND WEATHER
For
the
period
10
-
15 December
2024
Western/Nuwara
Eliya
Regions
Both regions reported bright mornings and sporadic
evening
showers throughout the week. Showers are expected in the Western and Nuwara Eliya regions in the week ahead according to the Department of Meteorology.
Uva/Uda Pussellawa
Regions
Rain was reported in the Uva and Uda Pussellawa regions throughout the week. The Department of Meteorology expects heavy showers in the Uva Region in the week ahead.
Low
Growns
The Low Grown Region reported bright mornings and evening showers throughout the week.
Crop
Intake
The Western, Nuwara Eliya, Uva and Udapussellawa regions maintained the crop intake, whilst the Low Grown Region showed a decrease.

Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers

Page 10
Page 10
BANGLADESH AUCTION
SALE OF - 17TH DECEMBER 2024 (SALE NO. 32)
CTC LEAF
: 58,461 packages of tea on offer met with a fair demand.
BROKENS
: Good liquoring Brokens were in quite good demand whilst larger types were in less demand with some withdrawals. The remainder met with a fairly good demand but eased in value compared to last. BLF teas met with an improved demand with a little less withdrawals.
FANNINGS
: Good liquoring Fannings met with a good demand but were mostly a little easier. Their Mediums and plainer varieties met with quite a fair demand and were generally firm on last except for the plainest which were an easier market. BLF teas met with an improved demand with a little less withdrawals.
DUST:
11,017 packages of tea on offer met with a fairly good demand. Good liquoring Dusts sold well at around last
levels. Mediums were an easier market by Tk.5/- to Tk.10/- following quality. Plain and BLF Dusts were an easier market and had more withdrawals than last. Blenders were supportive whilst Loose tea buyers were selective.
COMMENTS:
Offerings in this week's sale were slightly inferior in quality and these met with less competition particularly towards the close when withdrawals were also quite heavy except for the good varieties. Blenders were the mainstay of the market but the Loose tea buyers were subdued.
Good liquoring Dusts were the main attraction of the market.
Our Catalogue: (Sale 32) Avg : Tk 213.97, Sold 59.74% , (Sale 31) Avg : Tk 216.40, Sold 67.85%.

MARKET REPORT:
Market opened to good demand. Assams maintaining quality around last. Browner fibrous sorts selling at lower levels. Dooars and Cachar not seen yet.
BUYING PATTERN:
Western India: Operating on the better sorts
HUL : Operating
TCPL: Selective so far
Exporters : Some enquiry on bolder brokens and fannings
KOLKATA SALE  ORTHODOX MARKET
MARKET REPORT:
Market opened to good demand. Nominal quantity of tippy teas on offer readily absorbed. Well made and cleaner whole leaf and brokens tending irregular around last. Remainder browner stalkier whole leaf, brokens and secondaries  irregularly lower following quality.
BUYING PATTERN:
Middle East : Active
CIS:  Good Support
Courtesty - J Thomas & Company Private Limited
JAKARTA AUCTION
SALE OF - 16TH DECEMBER 2024 (SALE NO. 50)
CTC LEAF
DEMAND:
-
Good Demand.
MARKET:-
The total CTC leaf teas sold this week was
89.01% (1,449,150.39kgs)
of the total offering of
1,627,988.11Kgs.
Best teas continue to sell firm to dearer prices closely following quality and competition. Modest volume of good category bolder grades were on offer and sold in line with quality. Other sorts in this category sold dearer by Rs 3 to 4. The larger broken in all the other categories sold dearer by Rs 6 to 8 or more, whilst the remainders sold dearer by Rs 2 to 3.
BUYING PATTERN: -
The major blenders absorbed
51.65%
of the total CTC leaf sold. Regional packateers were active on the best & good teas . Up country buyers and local traders were fairly active. Exporters improved their buying especially on the larger broken grade.
ORTHODOX
LEAF
DEMAND:
-
Good demand..
MARKET:
-
Whole leaf and broken sold at firm to dearer following quality. Fanning sold at barely steady prices.
BUYING
PATTERN:
-
Exporters were fairly active on all sorts. Internal traders improved their buying on broken and fanning.
CTC
DUST
DEMAND:
-
Good lmproved Demand.
MARKET:
-
CTC dust offer this week was at
370,594.34Kgs
of which
345,900.73kgs
were sold
(93.34%)
.
Best category dust sold firm to dearer closely following quality with select few invoices fetching handsome gains.Good category bolder dust sold easier following quality, finer dust fetched firm to dearer prices. Better medium dust sold firm to dearer. Medium and plainer teas sold dearer by up to Rs 3 to 4.
BUYING PATTERN: -
Major blenders were fairly active along with the local and regional packateers. The up-country buyers were selective. Exporters fair support especially on medium and plainer sorts.
ORTHODOX
DUST
DEMAND: -
Good demand.
MARKET: -
Primary dust sold at barely steady to easier prices. Secondary dust sold at steady prices, however dusty secondaries continue to face withdrawals.
BUYING
PATTERN:
-
Internal & regional packateers were active on primary dust. Exporters continued to be selective on the secondary dust.
Courtesy - J.Thomas & Co. Pvt. Ltd.,
